name: Goldie Hawn
religion: Hawn was raised Jewish, still identifies with Judaism to some extent, but is also a Buddhist and a "Jesus freak." She's all over the map.
politicalViews: Similarly, Hawn is diverse. She has donated money to mostly Democrats, endorsed Libertarian candidates, and is pro-Israel.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Goldie Hawn was born in Washington D.C. and raised in Takoma Park, Maryland, just outside of D.C.
Hawn was raised by a Jewish mother and Presbyterian father.
content.sourceTitle: Goldie Hawn interview with Deborah Caldwell of Beliefnet

content.text: She describes her father as mostly non-religious–though philosophical by nature–and her mother as quite connected to her Jewish roots.
content.sourceTitle: Goldie Hawn interview with Deborah Caldwell of Beliefnet

content.text: Hawn's religious awakening came early. When she was still in grade school, during the Cold War, she recalls being scared out of her wits at the thought of nuclear annihilation. She said:

When I realized this fear, this uncertainty, this potential of dying, I guess I needed something greater to hold onto than what we can see, touch, and smell-and that was the spiritual aspect of God, the nature of God and his relationship to humans.
content.sourceTitle: Goldie Hawn interview with Deborah Caldwell of Beliefnet

content.text: Now, Hawn is among Hollywood's most spiritual celebrities. She's widely touted as a Buddhist
content.sourceTitle: Top 10 Famous Buddhists No 6 Goldie Hawn

content.text: –and she's even started a foundation to teach young children the benefits of meditation and mindfulness, though it has encountered some resistance.
content.sourceTitle: Goldie Hawn Pushing TM and Buddhism in Public Schools

content.text: But one gets the sense that Hawn wouldn't like being pigeonholed as simply another Buddhist. When pressed, she'll call herself a "Jewish Buddhist" but for the most part, she's not into labels.
She has said:

Your spirituality is shared by your actions and your interconnectedness with your family and everybody else. It's not conceptual. What's going to make you whole is your self-reflection and examination of yourself.
content.sourceTitle: Goldie Hawn interview with Deborah Caldwell of Beliefnet

content.text: But it goes even further. It's not just Judaism and/or Buddhism. Hawn has described herself as a "Jesus freak" too, saying:

He went to the desert; he sat quietly. He sat so quietly that he heard the voice of God. He heard the truth. He felt the truth. He was able to receive the truth because he emptied himself and he had the ability to do it.
content.sourceTitle: Goldie Hawn interview with Deborah Caldwell of Beliefnet

content.text: If there was anyone ever worthy of the "meta-religious" tag, it's Goldie Hawn.
Gold politics and the silver screen

It would seem that much more of Hawn's energy goes to spiritual matters than does to matters of state and society. That's not to say she isn't political, it's just not such a big deal to her. She said:
Well, I have my own private views. I don't really care to… I mean, I'm an actress and a mother and a citizen, but I don't want to be identified as a political figure.
content.sourceTitle: Interview: Susan Sarandon and Goldie Hawn

content.text: But there are some mention-worthy items. Let's see. Well, her financial political donations have gone overwhelmingly to Democrats. Between 1980 and 2004, she gave $32,540 to Democrat politicians and a paltry $500 to Republicans.
content.sourceTitle: Goldie Hawn's Federal Campaign Contribution Report

content.text: She spoke out against the war in Iraq–though only under durress, and she advocated for the removal of Saddam Hussein, peacefully of course.
content.sourceTitle: Interview: Susan Sarandon and Goldie Hawn

content.text: However, in one issue, she seems to side with conservatives–that being her support of the Jewish National Fund, for which she's taken some flack from pro-Palestinian activists.
content.sourceTitle: Protestors heckle Goldie Hawn at Scots charity event

content.text: Further distancing herself from the liberal crowd, Hawn endorsed Libertarian president Gary Johnson in the 2012 election.
content.sourceTitle: Election 2012: Obama, Romney, Johnson? Ask Katy Perry, Meat Loaf, Willie Nelson

content.text: That's a bit shocking. Here's a
picture
of them at a business conference.
I guess we'll call her a Libertarian–and a liberal, maybe a conservative? It's about as confusing as her religion. What do you guys think?

Permission.value:
• The photo has no copyright markings on it as can be seen in the links above and in the unedited copy of the file showing both front and back.
  • No copyright registered for this photo.
  • It was created for publicity purposes-distribution to the media and the image was meant to bring attention and publicity for actors and actresses. See also film still article.

Film production expert Eve Light Honathaner in The Complete Film Production Handbook, (Focal Press, 2001 p. 211.):

"Publicity photos (star headshots) have traditionally not been copyrighted. Since they are disseminated to the public, they are generally considered public domain, and therefore clearance by the studio that produced them is not necessary."
"There is a vast body of photographs, including but not limited to publicity stills, that have no notice as to who may have created them." (The Professional Photographer's Legal Handbook By Nancy E. Wolff, Allworth Communications, 2007, p. 55.)
Creative Clearance-Publicity photos
"Publicity Photos (star headshots) older publicity stills have usually not been copyrighted and since they have been disseminated to the public, they are generally considered public domain and therefore there is no necessity to clear them with the studio that produced them (if you can even determine who did)."
